The move has taken many by surprise, coming less than two weeks after his trade from the Baltimore Ravens to the Philadelphia Eagles. The 28-year-old cornerback was once regarded as one of the NFL ’s most dynamic defenders.

Article Title: “It's so demeaning”: Donald Trump blasts NFL’s new kickoff rule, urges Roger Goodell to bring back football’s traditional excitement
Article Text:
Donald Trump has voiced strong disapproval of the NFL's new kickoff rule, deeming it "terrible" and "demeaning" to the game's tradition and excitement. Speaking on The Pat McAfee Show, the former President argued that the changes, intended for player safety, have stripped the play of its "power" and "beautiful chaos," sparking renewed debate on preserving football's identity versus prioritizing safety.

Donald Trump reignites debate on tradition versus safety in football’s evolving identity

More coverage on NFL:

Donald Trump has once again inserted himself into the heart of an NFL controversy, this time over the league’s revamped kickoff rule. Speaking candidly on The Pat McAfee Show, the 79-year-old President expressed his deep frustration with the NFL’s decision to alter one of football’s most iconic plays.Donald Trump, who has long prided himself on defending American sports traditions, argued that the new “dynamic kickoff” model strips away the energy, unpredictability, and excitement that defined the sport for generations. His remarks come as players, fans, and analysts continue to debate whether the league’s safety-driven reforms are eroding football’s identity.Donald Trump didn’t hold back, saying, “I do have to say and I'll probably get myself into a little trouble for this - I hate the kickoff in football. I think it's so terrible, I think it's so demeaning. I think it hurts the game. I think it hurts the pageantry. I told that to Roger Goodell.”He added that despite the NFL’s claims of improved player safety, “you still have guys crashing into each other,” calling the reform “the opposite of what the game should be.” The President emphasized that the traditional kickoff represented “the power of the game,” a symbolic and thrilling start to every matchup that should never have been altered.Under the 2024 rule changes, players are lined up closer together, and no one can move until the ball is caught or hits the ground, measures designed to reduce high-speed collisions. Yet Trump argues these tweaks have “hurt the game’s pageantry,” transforming what was once a dynamic, adrenaline-fueled play into a controlled formality.The NFL has yet to respond to Donald Trump’s comments, but his criticism has revived a long-standing debate among fans and former players. While some applaud the league’s effort to protect athletes, others believe the game’s spirit is being sanitized beyond recognition. For Donald Trump, the issue goes beyond rule, it’s about preserving football’s essence, unpredictability, and “beautiful chaos” that made America fall in love with the sport in the first place.
Article Summary: Donald Trump has voiced strong disapproval of the NFL's new kickoff rule, deeming it "terrible" and "demeaning" to the game's tradition and excitement. Speaking on The Pat McAfee Show, the former President argued that the changes, intended for player safety, have stripped the play of its "power" and 'beautiful chaos'

Article Title: Taylor Swift’s fake $15.5 million donation rumor goes viral but her fans turned the rumor into real action
Article Text:
Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce (Getty Imagrs)

Taylor Swift’s fake $15.5 million donation goes viral amid SNAP funding fight





More coverage on NFL:



When Taylor Swift ’s name trends online, it’s usually because of a new song, a record-breaking tour, or her NFL love story with Travis Kelce . But this week, the internet turned her into a headline for a completely different reason, a fake donation claim that got way too real.A viral post on X claimed that Swift donated $15.5 million from a “nonexistent secret album” to food-equity charities, supposedly to help Americans struggling under new SNAP (Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program) restrictions. Only one small problem, it never happened.The claim tied Swift to a mysterious “Life of a Showgirl” album that, according to the post, was quietly released and its proceeds donated to fight hunger. But fact-checkers and Swift’s team quickly shut it down, there’s no record of any such album or donation.Still, the story spread like wildfire. The timing didn’t help either. It surfaced just as the Supreme Court began reviewing a major dispute over SNAP funding following a federal court order, reigniting debate over food aid for 42 million Americans.For many online, the rumor sounded just believable enough. Swift’s history of real-life generosity (from paying tour crew bonuses to donating to food banks) made the false story feel almost on brand.Beyond the celebrity buzz, the post spotlighted a very real crisis. The SNAP program, which provides food assistance to more than 41.7 million people has been under political and financial strain.Swift’s fanbase wasn’t about to let the moment go to waste. A group called Swifties for Hope launched a verified campaign encouraging fans to donate “$13 or whatever you can” to Feeding America and local food banks.Within days, they raised over $22,000, equivalent to around 220,000 meals for families in need. The irony? A fake post inspired real-world generosity, proof that Swifties don’t need a rumor to take action.This isn’t the first time a false celebrity donation has gone viral, but it may be one of the few that led to actual good. It highlights the messy relationship between misinformation and activism and how online communities can pivot a misleading trend into something meaningful.Even without a $15.5 million check, Swift’s fans made an undeniable impact.Taylor Swift hasn’t commented on the viral post, but her fandom’s response speaks for itself. The “fake news” may have fooled the internet, but it also turned into a moment of unity, empathy, and awareness around food insecurity.
Article Summary: A viral post on X claimed that Swift donated $15.5 million from a “nonexistent secret album” to food-equity charities. The claim tied Swift to a mysterious “Life of a Showgirl” album that, according to the post, was quietly released and its proceeds donated to fight hunger. There’s no record of any such album or donation.

Article Title: “He was so skilled” – Lakers legend Magic Johnson mourns loss of his dear NBA friend who passed away after battling cancer
Article Text:
Magic Johnson. Image via: Derek White/ Getty Images

Micheal Ray Richardson remembered by Magic Johnson and NBA peers



Micheal Ray Richardson. Image via: Mario Carlini - Iguana Press on Getty Images

Micheal Ray Richardson’s story of redemption beyond the NBA



The loss of Micheal Ray Richardson has left the NBA world mourning. The electrifying former NBA star passed away at 70 after a short battle with prostate cancer. Known as “Sugar” for his smooth game and effortless flair, Richardson’s death left many in the basketball community heartbroken, including Lakers legend Magic Johnson. The four-time NBA All-Star, who once dazzled crowds with his blend of scoring, defense, and swagger, spent his final days in Oklahoma surrounded by loved ones.Richardson’s passing has shaken a generation of players who saw in him both brilliance and redemption. The former New York Knicks and New Jersey Nets star carved a place in basketball history with unmatched athleticism and skill. His personal and basketball qualities made him a favorite among his peers and a force on the court.Magic Johnson paid a heartfelt tribute to his longtime friend, writing on X, “My good friend and 4-time NBA All Star Michael Ray Richardson passed away today. Michael Ray could do everything on the basketball court! He was so skilled and talented. He will be missed. I’ll be praying for the family. R.I.P.”Johnson’s words reflected the sentiments of many who played alongside or against Richardson. Hall of Famer Isiah Thomas called him “the player who gave me the most problems playing against him,” adding, “He was taller, just as fast, and could shoot from 3 and midrange.His post-up game was elite. Offensively, he had it all.” Former guard Quinn Buckner echoed that admiration, telling Andscape, “Back when he played in the NBA, the best guards were Magic [Johnson] and then Sugar. ”Richardson entered the NBA as the fourth overall pick in 1978 and quickly earned a reputation as one of the league’s most complete guards. Over eight seasons with the Knicks, Golden State Warriors, and Nets, he became a four-time All-Star and three-time league leader in steals. His 1985 season with the Nets, averaging 20.1 points, 8.2 assists, and 3.0 steals, remains one of the finest by a point guard in that era.Richardson’s career, though glittering, was marred by personal struggles that led to his lifetime ban from the NBA in 1986 for violating the league’s drug policy. But rather than fade into obscurity, he rebuilt his life overseas. He found success playing and later coaching in Europe, guiding teams to championships in Italy, France, and Canada.In 2024, Richardson published his memoir, Banned: How I Squandered an All-Star NBA Career Before Finding My Redemption, detailing his journey through hardship, recovery, and purpose. His attorney John Zelbst remembered him as “a great sportsman” who “overcame the most incredible odds to accomplish what he did.” Richardson’s demise has left a huge void, but he has built a career for which he will be remembered forever in the history books of the NBA.Also Read: Caitlin Clark’s golf round takes hilarious twist as Sophie Cunningham vows to heckle with beer in hand
Article Summary: Micheal Ray Richardson, a four-time NBA All-Star and three-time league leader in steals, has died at 70. Known as ‘Sugar’ for his smooth game and effortless flair, Richardson’s death has left many in the basketball community heartbroken.
